Description: Wheel-made pottery lamp with a double-convex body, an inward-sloping rim defined by a groove, a solid lug on the left side, a short tapering flat-topped nozzle with a rounded end, and a ring-base with a flat boss in the centre. Covered with a thin red-brown metalic slip, possibly intended as a black glaze. A small piece is missing from the body. Red brown fabric with dark grey reduced core. Fine mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Egyptian copy of Athenian type (Howland 1958, Type 25 and 32), or Rhodian predecessors (Bailey 1975, 250). Late 4th or 3rd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Blondé 1998, 314-20, no. 13, see also no. 4). 3rd century BC parallels from Tell Atrib (Młynarczyk 2012, type TA 1.4 and TA 1.9 which continues into early 2nd century BC). Bailey dates this to the early 3rd century BC (Bailey 1975, Q533). Blondé, F. 1998. Lampes tournée Hellénistiques du Musée D’Alexandrie, in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 307-35. Howland, R.H. 1958. The Athenian Agora, IV, Greek lamps and their survivals, Princeton. Młynarczyk, J. 2012. Tell Atrib 1985-1995. Vol. 3: Terracotta oil lamps. Varsovie : Éditions Neriton.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q533)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.58) (Phase 1)
